segments.key_quote: He is called undisturbed, Dheera, who goes to an unknown remote place and freed from all obligations quits his material body when it has become useless.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 26th verse of the 13th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, explaining its meaning about leaving the body in a remote place when it becomes useless, and Vidura's advice to Dhritarashtra.
segments.transcript: In this session we will be discussing from two verses, the 26th and the 27th verses of the Shri Advaitha Gadadhara Shri Vasadi Gauravakta Vrinda of the 13th chapter of the first canto of Shri Madbhagavatam. The 26th verse: Gata Swartham Imam Deham Virakto Mukta Bandhanaha Avignyata Gatir Jahyat Savay Dheera Udah Hruthaha. So far Vidura has been describing the condition of the Trashtra, which is a miserable condition, a degraded life he is leading, not preparing himself for death. Now he is giving a practical solution: what should the Trashtra do? He has already told him, quit home, leave home immediately and do what? That is going to come in the next few verses. So this 26th verse, the meaning is, he is called undisturbed, undisturbed means Dheera, who goes to an unknown remote place and freed from all obligations quits his material body when it has become useless. So what is the meaning of this, going to a remote unknown place and quitting the material body when one has, when the body has become useless?

segments.key_quote: One who has spoiled his life without such cultural activities is advised to leave home without knowledge of friends and relatives, and being thus freed from all obligations of family, society, country, etc., give up the body at some unknown destination.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Srila Prabhupada's purport on the verse, emphasizing the importance of devotional service in human life and the recommendation for those who haven't engaged in it to leave home and give up the body in an unknown place.
segments.transcript: That is explained by Srila Prabhupada in the purport. Narottam Das Thakur, a great devotee and acharya of the Gaudiya Vaishnava sect, has sung, Narottam Das Thakur, my lord, I have simply wasted my life, having obtained the human body I have neglected to worship your lordship and therefore I have willingly drunk poison. This is a part of a song written by Srila Narottam Das Thakur, one of the previous acharyas. So Srila Prabhupada explains, in other words, the human body is especially meant for cultivating knowledge of devotion and service to the Lord, without which life becomes full of anxieties and miserable conditions. Therefore, one who has spoiled his life without such cultural activities is advised to leave home without knowledge of friends and relatives and being thus freed from all obligations of family, society, country, etc., give up the body at some unknown destination so that others may not know where and how he has met his destiny, where and how he has met his death. This is the recommendation for somebody who has not taken up devotional service to fully engage in devotional service at the time of old age. Before death comes is the best remedy for facing death and achieving perfection of the human form of life. But if somebody, let us say, is in the middle of death, has not practiced, not prepared that way then better to quit home without knowledge of friends and relatives in such a way that one may give up the body in some unknown place.

segments.key_quote: Quit home is possible only for a dhira. Dhira means undisturbed. This is however the path of renunciation based on a frustrated life is for those who are unable to take to devotional service and are experiencing the miserable conditions especially in old age.
segments.summary: The speaker continues explaining Prabhupada's purport, defining 'dhira' as one who is undisturbed and can give up family life, and clarifying that this path of renunciation is for those frustrated with material life and unable to take up devotional service.
segments.transcript: And without the knowledge of anyone else. So Srila Prabhupada further explains, dhira means one who is not disturbed even when there is sufficient provocation. One cannot give up a comfortable family life due to his affectionate relationship with wife and children. Self-realization is obstructed by such undue affection for family and if anyone is at all able to forget such a relation he is called undisturbed or dhira. To be able to forget that bond of affection for family members and thereby quit home is possible only for a dhira. Dhira means undisturbed. This is however the path of renunciation based on a frustrated life is for those who are unable to take to devotional service and are experiencing the miserable conditions especially in old age.

segments.key_quote: But stabilization of such renunciation is possible only by association with bona fide saints and self-realized souls by which one can be engaged in the loving devotional service of the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that renunciation alone is not enough; association with devotees and engaging in devotional service under proper guidance are crucial for stabilization and liberation, highlighting Dhritarashtra's fortune in having Vidura's association.
segments.transcript: But Srila Prabhupada says this is a recommendation of accepting the path of renunciation based on frustrated life. But stabilization of such renunciation is possible only by association with bona fide saints and self-realized souls by which one can be engaged in the loving devotional service of the Lord. So what is Prabhupada saying here? That you may accept the path of renunciation giving up the miserable condition of material existence based on experiencing frustration living such a miserable life. But you cannot become stable and fixed up in that renounced life. Simply by going away from home and remaining undisturbed. No. You have to positively engage in pure devotional service under the guidance of pure devotees like Vidura. Sincere surrender unto the lotus feet of the Lord is possible by awakening the transcendental sense of service. This is called awakening of the divine sense of service. This is made possible by association with pure devotees of the Lord. Sadhu Sangha. Dhritarashtra was lucky enough to have a brother whose very association was a source of liberation for his frustrated life. So Dhritarashtra was very very fortunate because Vidura specially came to the palace of Hastinapura to deliver Dhritarashtra.

segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 27th verse, explaining that the best course of action is to understand the falsity of material existence through enlightenment from devotees and depend fully on Krishna within the heart when renouncing the world.
